item.title: 10 Steam Next Fest Demos You Need To Try - February 2026
item.content:encoded:
Itâ€™s one of my favorite times of the year â€“ when game developers come out like Santaâ€™s elves and show off what theyâ€™ve been working on in their hidden little workshops. Thatâ€™s right, itâ€™s time for another Steam Next Fest, and for the February Steam Next Fest of 2026, there are over 3,500 demos for people to try.

With all those demos to try, no one can play them all. But to help you out Iâ€™ve spent the last few weeks trying a bunch of them, and Iâ€™m here to point out 10 of the demos you really should check out. Some of them are popular, some of them are obscure, and Iâ€™ve tried to capture a variety of genres here so that thereâ€™s something for everyone.

With all of that here are ten of the best and most interesting February 2026 Steam Next Fest Demos.

Vampire Crawlers

There were two dungeon crawlers in this Next Fest that fought for space in this top 10, and Vampire Crawlers beat out the boomer shooter inspired Dungeons of Dusk by New Blood in a messy match. Vampire Crawlers's sheer energy and style plays near perfectly mixing dungeon crawlers, roguelite deckbuilding, and the Vampire Survivors IP into a cascade of fun.

It has some distinct and unique ideas that play differently in spots like the Crawler cards, and it feels really good to play. This was a demo I lost hours in, in a way that I never really have with Vampire Survivors itself.

Voidling Bound

I originally came across Voidling Bound last year, as they released their demo originally last spring. Iâ€™m happy that I can now talk about this monster taming/collecting game in this article, because it is a lot of fun. It takes that idea of finding and collecting monsters and turns it into a third-person shooter as you take control of the little creatures, called Voidlings, and explore and battle on different missions.

The controls are snappy, the combat fluid, and the variation in creatures and abilities intriguing. Voidling Bound is at its best in its exploration levels, but thereâ€™s fun in its hoard levels as well, and the mixture makes for a compelling proposition.

Bobo Bay

Sticking with cute little creatures, if you want a less action-packed game with little dudes, Bobo Bay might be up your alley. This is a game that takes inspiration from raising sims, and the Chao Garden from Sonic Adventure and has you raising these little creatures around and putting them into competitions. 

Get them trained up, fed up, and put them into competitions that their skills are best suited to and eventually into even bigger projects. Beyond that thereâ€™s a cheerful energy that infuses the game, and it's fun to move around in a way that a lot of games just donâ€™t have.

Battlestar Galactica: Shattered Hopes

From the persistently cheerful realm of Bobo Bay, we go to the darkness of space, and that no less of the 12 Colonies. In command of a small fleet escaping the Cylon destruction, you must guide them through tough decisions and difficult battles as you attempt to rejoin the Battlestar Galactica with your own ship and the civilians you are protecting. More than anything, Shattered Hopes captures the feel of the modern Battlestar Galactica with the grimness, the desperation, and the constant need to keep moving.

Itâ€™s not the highest production tie-in, nor are its battles incredibly complicated, but they are tense, short, and designed to press you to make decisions and accept tradeoffs before you are able to jump away.

Fading Echo

This is a fast-paced action-adventure RPG game where you find yourself in control of elements and able to reshape the world around you with it. Turn into a ball of water like Samusâ€™ morph ball and use that to put out fires or bounce around and through the water. 

Add in some cheek, and other elements to play with and Fading Echo is a lot of fun to move around, to explore, to solve puzzles, and fight in.

Celestial Return

A story-driven RPG experience, Celestial Return posits a dark, and intriguing world where you play as a burnt-out detective who decides to care one last time. Disco Elysium meets Blade Runner with an intriguing way of handling luck by treating dice as a resource used for just about everything, and they come in a variety of forms. Combine that with a unique aesthetic and this is a must-play game.

Darkhaven

Like many of my generation, I grew up with Diablo 2, and that game is still shaping things with its new expansion and everything else. Somewhere along the way though, the ARPG genre kinda decided that it had already reached peak and just began doing small tweaks on the same format. Donâ€™t get me wrong, I love games like Torchlight too, but I also wonder if anyone was going to ever move the line.

Well, some of the Diablo and Torchlight crew are back with Darkhaven and their big idea is essentially to mix the ARPG with survival games. Take the items and quests and mix that with the building and destructible world of Minecraft, and you know what it? It works. The whole part of the world being so changeable creates significant differences in how the game plays, and new exploration options. Building here is kept simple so you arenâ€™t tracking 30 things, and it gives the game a distinct feel.

Darkhavenâ€™s demo here is rawer than others, as the game is also currently on Kickstarter seeking funding for another year of development. Right now what you have is a pre-alpha where you can see a lot of the seams and raw edges showing, but thereâ€™s a lot of promise here and room for something that is very different from what came before.

Titanium Court

The most surreal game I experienced throughout Next Fest, Titanium Court is out there and it is weird in many many ways. The fourth wall gets leaned on, the world in it is odd, and its got weird-as-hell characters and interface interactions at times that delight in their surreal absurdism.

While that might be enough to get interest, what youâ€™ll find underneath is a deep strategy matching game that is unique in how it plays. The closest in someways is something like Drop Dutchy, but this focuses on match-3 type mechanics, and how different types of blocks and your subjects all interact as you try to maximize returns, minimize invasions, and find your way through a bizarre and compelling narrative.

Windrose

One of the interesting things you can watch at times on Steam is the population of survival-craft players. They emerge from one and will seemingly migrate en masse to another game. Sometimes you can even predict what the next one will be â€“ and Windrose looks like it.

And I mean, why not? It looks good, it's a golden age of piracy themed survival game, and it plays pretty well too. It has a bit more combat depth then many of these games, but features all the same tracks you would expect while having a few different things and a focus on sailing and finding treasure that you donâ€™t see elsewhere necessarily in the genre. Arr Matey, hoist the jolly roger and prepare to battle as we seek revenge on Blackbeard himself!

Vultures - Scavengers of Death

Have you ever wondered, what would Resident Evil be like if it was turn based? Well you donâ€™t need to really wonder any more, as Vultures â€“ Scavengers of Death here presents a pitch-perfect take on the '90s horror styling turned into a tactics type experience. Seek what is causing the infected mutants (totally not zombies) to cause problems while managing your scarce resources and gathering more.

Avoid combat where you can, beat enemies where you must, and wonder â€“ what is that around that corner?

A longtime lover of speculative fiction, in almost all its forms, Don joined TechRaptor in 2014 on a whim sending in an application as he was looking forâ€¦ More about Don

item.title: How strong is New York's "illegal gambling" case against Valve's loot boxes?
item.content:encoded:
Skip to content

Canâ€™t win if you donâ€™t play

Lawyers tell Ars the state has a tough road ahead, even as Valve is uniquely vulnerable.

Opening a vauable skin like this in a loot box is akin to winning a lottery, New York alleges in a new lawsuit. Credit: Twitter / Luksusbums

For years now, Valve fans have been making jokes about the companyâ€™s slow transition from game maker to glorified digital hat and knife paint marketplace. This week, though, a lawsuit brought by the state of New York argues that Valveâ€™s in-game loot box sales amount to an illegal gambling outfit worth tens of billions of dollars.

Lawyers who have looked into the particulars of the case tell Ars that the state faces an uphill battle in convincing courts that this portion of Valveâ€™s business legally constitutes gambling. That said, there are a few elements of the case that might make Valve legally vulnerable to the stateâ€™s arguments.

What is gambling, anyway?

For a game to legally be counted as â€œgamblingâ€ in most jurisdictions, it has to pass a three-part test: a player has to pay money (1) for an outcome thatâ€™s materially determined by chance (2) in the hopes of receiving something of value (3). While buying a key to a loot box in a Valve game easily passes those first two tests, New Yorkâ€™s legal case will likely hinge on whether the random cosmetic items players get from those loot boxes constitute â€œsomething of valueâ€ for statutory purposes.

Even though loot box purchasers donâ€™t know what item theyâ€™ll get, the fact that they know theyâ€™re getting something for their money could matter legally. â€œGambling traditionally means risking money and possibly getting nothing,â€ Foundation Law Group Counsel Jonathan Loiterman told Ars. â€œHere, buyers canâ€™t lose their stake in the traditional gambling sense; they always receive an item. That looks more like buying a randomized product than placing a bet.â€

In this way, Valveâ€™s loot boxes are more akin to physical â€œblind boxâ€ toy sales or collectible card packs than a game like blackjack or roulette. In the real world, these kinds of randomized sales â€œare not considered gambling because the stated value of what you receive is unchanging,â€ Hoeg Law Firm attorney Richard Hoeg told Ars. â€œYou pay for a pack of cards, you get a pack of cards.â€

That â€œstated valueâ€ logic can sometimes be even stronger in the digital realm, where the randomized items you get from a loot box are locked to your account and canâ€™t easily be resold. â€œDigital sellers usually try to get around this by stating that everything sold has zero cash value, so you are always getting â€˜nothing,â€™â€ as Hoeg put it.

Come to our Marketplace

Where Valve might have some unique legal exposure, lawyers tell Ars, is in its operation of the Steam Marketplace, where players can trade in-game items for Steam Wallet funds. Operating that kind of official exchange for players to extract value from items won â€œstarts to look a lot more like gambling,â€ Hoeg said.

â€œThe problem here is 100% the ability to resell the items from the loot boxes,â€ attorney and video game law expert Mark Methenitis tells Ars. â€œA loot box/gacha mechanic is fine when you canâ€™t turn around and resell the items because youâ€™re not getting something of value. When Valve is also providing a marketplace for those items, theyâ€™ve added the third element.â€

Still, Loiterman said that the existence of the Steam Marketplace resale market â€œmatters, but itâ€™s not decisiveâ€ in this case. While taking a commission on digital item sales â€œstrengthens the argument that these items have economic value,â€ that fact alone â€œdoesnâ€™t transform a randomized purchase into gambling,â€ he added.

Part of the problem for New Yorkâ€™s argument is that the Steam Wallet funds players receive for selling their items can only be spent on the Steam platform, putting them a few steps away from cold, hard cash or even casino chips. And while New Yorkâ€™s lawsuit argues that players can get cash out of their Steam Wallets by buying and reselling Steam Deck hardware in the real world, that argument is not a legal slam dunk.

â€œCalling it gambling because a user could, through several indirect steps, convert an item into cash risks stretching gambling law beyond its traditional limits,â€ Loiterman said. â€œIf New Yorkâ€™s theory wins, it raises uncomfortable questions about things like PokÃ©mon cards or promotional games (e.g. McDonaldâ€™s Monopoly). Courts will be cautious about going that far.â€

New York also argues that Valve tacitly endorses third-party services that allow players to easily â€œcash outâ€ their Steam inventories for real money. Whether Valve is culpable for the existence of those services is still an unsettled question in the law, Methenitis said, as it has been at least since he wrote about the legal implications of World of Warcraftâ€˜s third-party gold resellers nearly two decades ago.

â€œI think companies have a pretty strong [legal] argument if they make some attempts to police [third-party resellers]â€”they obviously canâ€™t fully control what people do outside their platform,â€ Methenitis said. â€œBut if they turn a blind eye to it and allow it, I think they could be found liable.â€ Loiterman agreed that Valve â€œproviding the tools that enable those [third-party] markets and tolerating them creates some degree of responsibility.â€

â€œJudges tend to be cautiousâ€¦â€

In the end, the lawyers Ars spoke to were generally skeptical that courts would determine that Valveâ€™s loot box system constitutes illegal gambling. Cases making similar arguments about other loot box systems have failed in other jurisdictions, â€œin part because gambling laws were drafted with casinos and lotteries in mind,â€ Loiterman said. â€œJudges tend to be cautious about breaking from an emerging consensus.â€

Hoeg agreed that â€œthe entire question [in this case] is novel, andâ€¦ the courts are (small-â€˜câ€™) conservative institutions, not generally wanting to adopt novel arguments without direction from the legislative branches.â€ Even if Valveâ€™s loot box system â€œmay start to smell a bit like gambling,â€ Hoeg said he would â€œhonestly be surprised if the courts went along with the characterization without a new law aimed at it.â€

â€œI view it as a weak case offered primarily for political grandstanding/coverage over real legal effect,â€ Hoeg concluded. â€œWe shall see, though.â€

Kyle Orland has been the Senior Gaming Editor at Ars Technica since 2012, writing primarily about the business, tech, and culture behind video games. He has journalism and computer science degrees from University of Maryland. He once wrote a whole book about Minesweeper.

item.title: Can Resident Evil Requiem Grapple With Nuclear Tragedy? Does It Even Want To?
item.content:encoded:
The Resident Evil series, historically, has been about a lot of things. Zombies, obviously, but also the global ravages of a feckless pharmaceutical company and, in its own often-campy way, the politics surrounding that. You might remember, for example, that time all of Raccoon City got obliterated by a nuclear bomb. Charged imagery, to be sure, but was Resident Evil 3 trying to say anything weighty or consequential with it back then? And what is Resident Evil Requiem, in returning to that setting, trying to say with it now? On the latest Aftermath Hours, we attempt to answer those questions.

This time around weâ€™re joined by two critics whoâ€™ve played through Requiem and articulated their thoughts about it: freelancer and Aftermath columnist Joshua Rivera and Polygon editor-at-large Giovanni Colantonio, whose review of Requiem â€“ which put the game in conversation with the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki â€“ has drawn some pretty vocal criticism these past few days. We discuss whether or not the text of the game actually supports that kind of close thematic read.

We also discuss Resident Evil more broadly: where itâ€™s coming from, where itâ€™s going, and of course, where Requiem fits into all of that. The series has spent its past few installments promising a fresh start; does Requiem actually deliver, or is it lured astray by the sirenâ€™s call of Leon Kennedy-flavored nostalgia? And during an era thatâ€™s decidedly post-zombie, what makes this series, in particular, so enduring?

Finally, we come up with some truly diabolical remake ideas for old-school games and conclude that thereâ€™s actually no such thing as a long or short game. Who needs to stick around for 100 hours when you can make your own ending whenever you want to?

You can find this week's episode below and on Spotify, Apple, or wherever else you prefer to listen to podcasts. If you like what you hear, make sure to leave a review so that we can acquire the venerated Radical Rex license and leave it in the capable hands of Sam Eng, creator of Skate Story.

Hereâ€™s an excerpt from our conversation (edited for length and clarity):

Giovanni: Itâ€™s tough because there are specific moments â€“ and this is the tough thing about a pre-release write up â€“ I want to point to that are off limits for now, and thereâ€™s a question to be had about â€œEh, maybe that should wait [until after release] to have the full scope of the thing.â€ Iâ€™ve always heard [Hiroshima and Nagasaki] referenced in terms of Resident Evil 3; Iâ€™ve heard people talk about that. Iâ€™ve never quite bought into it. Iâ€™ve always thought of it like the â€˜90s and â€œCool guys donâ€™t look at explosions.â€ Everything blows up in these games. I never paid much mind to that.

There are a couple moments in Requiem that I do think kind of, to varying degrees of explicitness, at least reference it. Not saying it specifically, but there is one case where I think it does actually point to it in a way thatâ€™s surprising. But I started thinking about it [in terms of] â€œIs this a game that is looking back at what happened in Resident Evil 3 and looking at it through the lens of a greater tragedy?â€ I was doing research into that, and I found an old research paper from 2019 that was focused on [original Resident Evil director] Shinji Mikamiâ€™s work. It was a piece about unpacking a lot of that post-war feeling in his work. I donâ€™t know that I even necessarily fully agree with that research paper. There were some parts of it where I was like â€œDino Crisis fits into this? I donâ€™t know. Seems like a stretch.â€ 

But I think it got the wheels turning, and with some of the symbols and lines that are in Requiem, I got to thinking about if this is a game about Leon dealing with a trauma that is referencing the trauma [of nuclear devastation]? And are we supposed to take it as heâ€™s experiencing this long aftermath of this trauma thatâ€™s coming from a real place of anxiety?

So thatâ€™s how I got onto that train of thought, and I do think there are things you can point to that are there. I think the question that arises, though, is: Even if that stuff is there, is Resident Evil equipped to talk about that in any way? Iâ€™ve been thinking about that a lot in the past couple days. This has always been a series that has political undertones in its lore. Thereâ€™s an evil Big Pharma company, and itâ€™s making bioweapons and trading those with the US government.

Nathan: Zombie president!     

Giovanni: Yeah, thereâ€™s weird threads. Theyâ€™ve always been kinda funny, but thereâ€™s also stuff in there thatâ€™s very strange and pointed. A distrust for authority is baked into all of Shinji Mikamiâ€™s work â€“ even Dino Crisis. So the question that arises for me that I havenâ€™t fully unpacked yet is, even if thatâ€™s what the reference is â€“ and I think itâ€™s fair to say â€œEh, thatâ€™s probably a stretchâ€ â€“ is Resident Evil as a series, a goofy thing, equipped to deal with something like that? And is any triple-A game? 

Josh, you wrote something that I really love; you say that even if games reference something like this, what do you do in the game? What does the gameplay come down to at the end of the day? Resident Evil Requiem, at the end of the day, is a big, fun shooting action game where youâ€™re killing zombies, and zombies are the bodies of the dead. How do we feel about that [in this context]?

Josh, is there space for Resident Evil as youâ€™ve talked about it, as a work of pure schlock, to talk about things and reference them, or should we take it as being a little too dumb to really say anything serious about this â€“ and interpreting it that way is kind of a foolâ€™s errand?

Joshua: I think itâ€™s a foolâ€™s errand. I also think the series is capable of [aspiring to something more serious] if they wanted to. My example in support of this is actually Resident Evil 7, which opens with a very clear Texas Chainsaw Massacre homage. Thereâ€™s some hicksploitation going on there. And it has a scene at the very end where you link with the mold, which is the evil presence â€“ itâ€™s very silly â€“ thatâ€™s made these people what they are. That neglect from this pharmaceutical company poisoned these peopleâ€™s land and turned them into monsters. You get to speak with the real Jack Baker, a sympathetic, tragic figure.

I think the game means that. I think the people behind the game were interested in some type of pathos because thatâ€™s part of what they wanted to do with that game: ground you not just in Ethan Winters and the first-person [perspective], but also relating to these characters as you would in the first-person. 

So I do think the games are capable of it; I donâ€™t think this game is interested in that. I donâ€™t think itâ€™s crazy for someone to see what you saw, Gio, and to consider it in relation to the game. But I do think there is a matter of scope and justification. Thatâ€™s a big check that you write â€“ that anybody writes if theyâ€™re pulling from something outside of the text. The sticking point for me, then, is â€œHow do I justify referencing a real historical tragedy and also a people in connection to that tragedy?â€

The first thing I would go to is just a simple question of visual language. I think about 9/11; because of the generation weâ€™re a part of, most people in the creative workforce are about our age or older. We have a visual language for how a city falls apart. We have a very specific image culturally for what that looks like. So if we are going to show a city falling apart, that is what weâ€™re gonna think of and that is what weâ€™re gonna replicate. Does it mean that the work in which we do that is about that? Not necessarily. Then again, this is also a matter of interpretation and intent. They could be totally separate things. This is what [the concept of] death of the author talks about.

For example, The Avengers. Thatâ€™s very much a movie about â€œWhat if we could stop 9/11?â€ Thatâ€™s not necessarily what the people who made that movie were thinking, but thatâ€™s kind of whatâ€™s in that movie. Or the new Superman movie â€“ maybe less so. I think that movie has different aims. 

You put even more of a burden of proof on yourself when you also invoke a people and a place and a culture in addition to the imagery of a historical event. Thatâ€™s where Iâ€™ve got my guard up. Iâ€™m gonna call out something specifically, and it was not something that was in your review; this is something I saw in defense of your review from people who read it, and it really bugged me. People were like â€œIt makes sense and itâ€™s natural to think of Hiroshima in a work made by Japanese people featuring a bombed city.â€ Itâ€™s one of those â€œListen to yourselfâ€ moments. Natural for you. That is your only frame of reference for this place, this people, this culture. You swap out any other atrocity with any other group of people, and fuck you, you know? â€œItâ€™s natural for this Latino man to be evoking colonialism and the conquest of Borinquen.â€ Listen to yourself. 

I think whatâ€™s interesting â€“ and what I struggle with a little bit in your reading, Giovanni â€“ is that you do evoke the Hibakusha [bombing survivors]. We know how Japanese culture evokes that imagery. They were a protected class. There is a very sober and sacred evocation of these people and what they went through. If we think this is something that is being referenced, I think we would also see that somber, careful treatment [in Requiem]. And I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s there. So for me, thatâ€™s not where I would go.

Giovanni: Yeah, fair enough. I think thatâ€™s a really interesting way to read it, because yeah, I agree: If we are talking about survivors, this is a tough series to put that into! And again, I do think there are little references to it â€“ there are things to my read that thatâ€™s coming from â€“ but I donâ€™t think that necessarily means thatâ€™s what the game is about.

I would actually argue, and I want to make this clear: I think the game, if weâ€™re giving it an About, is very broadly about trauma. Itâ€™s about Grace experiencing it on this micro scale, dealing with the loss of her mother; itâ€™s about Leon dealing with it on a larger scale of â€œAll these people in this city that I was sworn to protect are gone.â€ Itâ€™s having two characters face that in very different ways â€“ almost a fight or flight response between them. Thatâ€™s what I would say the game is actually about, and thatâ€™s the wider point that I would point to if we were getting into that. 

But yeah, I agree: If the intent is to invoke this [real-world tragedy], itâ€™s certainly not terribly respectful. And I think thatâ€™s a good point, to be like â€œWell, you would think that they would be more respectful if that was the case.â€ I think thatâ€™s legitimate.

item.title: Pokemon FireRed & LeafGreen Aurora Ticket and Mystic Ticket Confirmed in Switch Ports
item.content:encoded:
It's apparently been confirmed that Pokemon FireRed and LeafGreen on Switch have a quality-of-life feature that will make catching certain legendary Pokemon much, much easier.

As spotted by Professor Rex on X (and isn't that pleasing to say?), a Japanese speedrunner has uncovered a neat change in the Switch versions of the GBA classics, and it pertains to the Aurora Ticket and Mystic Ticket items.

In the original Game Boy Advance games, obtaining these tickets was only possible through Mystery Gift events, so if you wanted to catch the legendary Pokemon Deoxys, Ho-Oh, and Lugia, you'd need to have been around during those events. Now, that's no longer the case.

In the Switch version, however, both of those tickets are simply automatically handed to you upon beating the Elite Four, at least according to the aforementioned Japanese speedrunner's playthrough of the game.

This means that you'll have the chance to confront Deoxys, Ho-Oh, and Lugia over the course of a normal playthrough rather than needing to be in the right place at the right time, which is great news for those of us who chronically miss these kinds of events.

Just in case you missed the news, Pokemon FireRed and LeafGreen were re-released on Switch today as part of the franchise's 30th anniversary. Nintendo has also promised that the games will feature Pokemon Home compatibility at some point in the future.

These anniversary celebrations also saw the long-awaited announcement of Pokemon's tenth generation earlier today, with Pokemon Winds and Waves due to launch exclusively on Switch 2 sometime next year.

You can check out Pokemon FireRed and LeafGreen right now on Switch 2 and Switch via the eShop (there's no physical release available for them, unfortunately). Stay tuned for more news on all things Pokemon.

item.title: Amazon Reveals the First Look at Kratos and Atreus in God of War TV Series as Production Begins
item.content:encoded:
Amazon Prime Video has revealed our first look at Kratos and Atreus in the upcoming God of War TV series led by Ronald D. Moore, which we had previously learned was set to start filming in March 2026, has already kicked off with actors Ryan Hurst and Callum Vinson in full costume and makeup for their roles.

The image clearly depicts a scene from the very beginning of the God of War (2018) game, where Atreus and Kratos go hunting immediately after burning the ashes of Kratos' wife and Atreus' mom. Kratos is testing Atreus, to see if he is capable of making the journey that they are about to embark on to spread the ashes at the highest peak in all nine realms.

Of course, we know that the full journey encapsulates so much more than that, but as far as this first look goes, it's a pretty solid and iconic choice. The opening of the 2018 game is emotional and heavy, and this is a great callback to make for fans of the games, while also being a solid shot of the characters in their main roles of father and son.

With all of that said, the first comment under this photo, which is that this "Looks like a cosplay from E3 2018," and some of the other negative comments are not entirely out of line in their displeasure. God of War fans understand the importance of the scene, the costuming and makeup teams have clearly done a great job with getting everything about the look of Kratos and Atreus right, but at least in a single screenshot, it does not have the sense of magic and mythological wonder that the same scene in the game carries.

Maybe it's the fact that this is just a still image, with no music to support it, and that we have yet to hear how either actor sounds in these roles. Maybe once all those missing pieces are included, it'll actually look and feel how we might expect a God of War TV adaptation to look and feel.

Or maybe we'll start to see that when we see the rest of the cast in full makeup and costume. The most recent addition to the cast came earlier this week with Ed Skrein getting tapped to play Baldur. and now that the show has entered production, we'll hopefully soon learn who will be filling the last major role yet to be publicly revealed, Freya.

item.title: Thereâ€™s Hope PokÃ©mon TCG 30th Anniversary Cards Will Include Reprints Of All-Time Classics
item.content:encoded:
When it became obvious there was going to be no new mainline PokÃ©mon game in 2025, it raised a huge question about what would happen to the PokÃ©mon TCG. The three-yearly cycle had become so normal that the card game was built around it, releasing sets themed around the new monsters and mechanics added to each new gaming entry, so what would it do when that was taken away? The answer, it turned out, was the revival of Mega Evolution, loosely tied into the events of PokÃ©mon Z-A, but mostly just doing its own nostalgic thing. But now we know that PokÃ©mon Winds and Waves wonâ€™t be out until 2027! So what then? Step forward, the 30th Anniversary Set.

During the 30th anniversary PokÃ©mon Presents, among its lacking assortment of announcements, there was a brief appearance of the TCGâ€”albeit a very opaque one. The one solid piece of information we received was that the new cards willâ€”for the first time everâ€”release simultaneously worldwide. Cards are usually released in Japan first, in the countryâ€™s own bespoke sets, and then repurposed for the rest of the world in differently arranged and titled collections.

The minute-long inclusion showed a range of favorite cards from the last 30 years, often in non-English versions, before faux-interrupting itself to reveal Mew and Mewtwo seemingly on some sort of LSD trip. But nothing tangible, nothing we could infer. Could it be the case that this wasnâ€™t a gallery of old faves, but potentially cards that will be included in the new sets?

Thatâ€™s whatâ€™s being claimed by some sites, like Wargamer, convinced that the cards shown will be part of this celebratory series of sets. And you can see why, given the clip is so infuriatingly uninformative, and especially the choice to show the classic cards in very many different languages, and then finishing on the news that it will release simultaneously worldwide. It seems to speak to this international approach.

Iâ€™m not convinced. I think the intention here was to fly through the TCGâ€™s 30-year history, given the cards appeared in chronological order, beginning with that classic Chonkachu #58 and the infamous holo Charizard from the Base Set (although here shown as Glurak, its German name), before jumping to a French Palkia Lv. X from Diamond & Pearlâ€˜s Great Encounters and a Japanese Lugia from Wind from the Sea (2008 and 2002 respectively). We then get a Spanish Uxie Lv. 55 from Legends Awakened (also 2008), followed by the briefest glimpse of both halves of the Darkrai & Cresselia Legend from HS Triumphant (2010), a Genesect EX from 2013â€™s PokÃ©mon Blast, and a Chinese Solgaleo GX (2017 for the English version). Finally thereâ€™s a burst of four: Pikachu & Zekromâ€™s Tagteam from 2019â€™s Team Up in Thai, Zacian V from 2020â€™s Sword & Shield base set in Korean, Arceus VSTAR from 2022â€™s Brilliant Stars in Indonesian, and finally a silver-edged Amazing Rare Raikou from PokÃ©monâ€™s 2020 arrival in Chinese.

The only oddity in there is that Chinese Solgaleo GX, as at that point the game hadnâ€™t launched in China. It was, however, released as part of the Chinese Storming Emergence Radiant set in 2022, making it a really weird pick for this montage. My suspicion is less that this is an indication of a new version of the card, and more that someone made a cock-up.

There is of course precedent for re-releasing classic cards as part of an anniversary collection. For the 25th birthday in 2021, Celebrations was released which included the 25-card Classic Collection featuring reprints of various cards from the previous years, marked by a Pikachu head. Then there was 2016â€™s XY Evolutions that was primarily made up of reprints of Base Set cards, infuriatingly similar to the originals but for a tiny set symbol. So, yeah, itâ€™s entirely possible.

Weâ€™ve reached out to PokÃ©mon to see if we can get any clarification, but given PokeBeach is claiming the sets wonâ€™t start releasing until October of this year, it seems likely the company will keep quiet about it until nearer the end of this Mega Evolutions era.
